Briefly comprehending the Doctrine of diuer≈øe new Metallicall Inuentions, but e≈øpecially, how to neale, melt, and worke all kinde of mettle-oares, Irons and Steeles with Sea-coale, Pit-coale, Earth-coale and Bru≈øh-fewell.
Al≈øo a Tran≈øcript of his Maie≈øties Letters Pattents of Priuiledge, granted vnto Simon Sturteuant for the ≈øaid Metallicall bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, for one and thirty yeares.

div.head: The Preface to the Reader.
div.p:
GEntle Reader, I am not ignorant, how they that are willing to apprehend and a≈ø≈øi≈øt new bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, are de≈øirous to be ≈øati≈øfied in the≈øe points. Fir≈øt concerning the perfect and exact knowledge of that Inuention wherein they are to deale and negotiate, for as the common Prouerbe ≈øaith; Ignoti nulla cupido. The ≈øecond is, touching the worth and goodne≈ø≈øe of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and how the benefit thereof may bee rai≈øed. The third is the habillity of the Inuentioner, to effect and performe his proiect propounded. The fourth is concerning the manner of contracting or bargaining; In all which, I will endeauour to giue the be≈øt ≈øatisfaction that I may, out of the praecepts and grounds of this pre≈øent Treati≈øe of Metallica. And therefore concerning the fir≈øt point. The Tran≈øcript of his Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious grant and priuiledge doth euidently ≈øhew and informe the Reader, that among≈øt many other inuentions
granted for one and thirty yeares, my Selfe, my Executors, Deputies and A≈ø≈øignes, may onely make, practi≈øe, and put in v≈øe, within any of his Maie≈øties Realmes and Dominions, the working, melting, and effecting of Iron, Steele, and other Mettles with Sea-coale, or Pit-coale. The principall end of which inuention is, that the Woods and Timber of our country might be ≈øaued, maintained and pre≈øerued from the great con≈øumption and wa≈øte of our common Furnaces and Iron-Milnes, which as they are now ordinarily built and framed, can burne, ≈øpend, and con≈øume no other fewell but Char coale. The which deui≈øe if it may bee effected accordingly (as I make no doubt but by Gods ble≈ø≈øing I ≈øhall) will prooue to bee the be≈øt and mo≈øt profitable bu≈øine≈ø≈øe and Inuention that euer was knowne or inuented in England the≈øe many yeares.

For (to ≈øpeake nothing of the great benefit, and profit which may bee rai≈øed and made by twenty other Inuentions compri≈øed and
comprehended vnder the Pattent) the yearly vallew of this mettle-bu≈øine≈ø≈øe alone, will amount vnto 330. thou≈øand pounds, per annuÃÑ, after the ≈øecond or third yeare, as appeareth by this calculation.

div.head: A Calculation ≈øhewing how the Mettle Inuention or Art, which maketh all kinde of Mettles or Metalique ≈øubstance, with Pit-coale or Sea-coale, will bee worth per annum. 330. thou≈øand pounds, immediatly after the two fir≈øt yeares, which are the allotted times for Tryalls and Conformities, without any charges, (except the charges of Tryalls) to the Pattentees, Partners, A≈øsi≈øtants, and Dealers.
div.p:
THere are planted already in England and Wales, eight hundred Milnes for the making of Iron, for there are foure hundred Milnes in Surry, Kent, & Su≈ø≈øex,
as the towne≈ømen of Ha≈ølemore haue te≈øtified and numbred vnto mee, there are al≈øo 200. Milnes in Wales, and 20. in Nottingham≈øhire, as the Author hath beene credibly informed.
Now wee may well ≈øuppo≈øe, that all England, Scotland and Ireland (be≈øides the forenamed ≈øhires) will make vp the number of 180. Milnes more, being in all 800. Milnes.

Moreouer one Milne alone ≈øpendeth yearly in Charcoale 500. pound and more, as diuer≈øe Clarkes and workmen in Iron bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, haue credibly te≈øtified, which in pit-coale will be done with the charges of 30. or 40. pounds, after the Inuentioners manner and inuention, or at the mo≈øt with 50. pound, where carriage is farre and chargeable.

So that this new Inuention in the 800. Iron milnes, will ≈øaue and gaine de claro the owners of tho≈øe milnes 320. thou≈øand pounds yearly, ouer and aboue their ordinary and annuall gaines, as it appeareth by this proportion.
One Milne alone ≈øaueth yearely 400. li. Ergo, 800. Milnes ≈øaue yearly 320. thou≈øand pounds.

Againe the ≈øaid Metalique inuention, beeing put and conuerted to Lead, Tinne, Copper, Bra≈ø≈øe, and Gla≈ø≈øe-mettle, in all the ≈øeuerall Mineralls of England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, will que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe cleare yearely, by meanes of Fewell, aboue ten thou≈øand pounds more; ouer and be≈øides the ordinary gaines in the ≈øaid bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. So that the yearely Iron reuenues, added vnto the≈øe other Metalique reuenues, doe amount vnto 330. thou≈øand pounds, as was ≈øaid before.

Now out of the≈øe Metalique gaines of 330. thou≈øand pounds yearely, the owners of the Milnes, Hearths, and Furnaces, may haue and receiue liberall rates and proportions allowed and allotted vnto them, ouer and be≈øides their ordinary gaines, onely in lieu of conforming their Furnaces, Fineries and Chafferies to this Inuention of Pitt-coale
and Earth-coale. And al≈øo the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, the Prince his Highne≈ø≈øe, the Duke of Yorke, the Lord Vicount Rotche≈øter, and other parties interre≈ø≈øed in the Pattent, may by their Compo≈øition and agreement with the ≈øaid Owners and Iron-Mai≈øters, yearely receiue, by way of rents and licences, the re≈øidew of that gaines which remaineth ouer and aboue that which was allotted and allowed to the Iron-Mai≈øters, for applying of this Inuention to their ordinary way of making of Iron, as more fully ≈øhall bee ≈øpecified, ≈øhewed, and prooued in the Apendix of this Treati≈øe, which I am now preparing for the Printer and the Pre≈ø≈øe with all conuenient ≈øpeed.

This may ≈øuffice therefore, to giue the Reader ≈øatisfaction, concerning the two fir≈øt points, for the knowledge and the worth of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, and concerning the manner how certaine yearly annuities may bee rai≈øed to the dealers and a≈ø≈øi≈øtants.
Now to per≈øwade the third point, that the Authour is able to effect the worke vndertaken, in as ample manner as hee propoundeth; wee plead and alledge as followeth.

Fir≈øt the Inuentioner by his ≈øtudy, indu≈øtrie, and practi≈øe, hath already brought to pa≈ø≈øe and publi≈øhed diuer≈øe proiects and new deui≈øes, a≈øwell Litterall as Mechannicall, very beneficiall to the common-wealth. His Literare Inuentions doe appeare and are knowne partly by his Printed Treati≈øe of Dibere Adam, which is a Schola≈øticall engin Aucomaton, and partly in diuer≈øe other Manu≈øcripts which he hath to ≈øhew. His new Mechanicks already performed, are to bee ≈øeene in the Inuentions which hee calleth by the names of Pre≈ø≈øewares, Wood-pleits, Ballance, Engin, Baramyha, and Hubla, of all which in priuate ≈øpeech hee is ready more largely to conferre, and to manife≈øt their truth and goodne≈ø≈øe at his Workehou≈øes at I≈ølington and Highbury. To conclude,1. Sam. 17.34. Thus Dauid rea≈øoneth from the Beare and Lyon to Golyah the Gyant. therefore he doubteth not but (by Gods ble≈ø≈øing & a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, ≈øemblably with ≈øucce≈ø≈øe)
to effect his Inuention of Iron-works, as al≈øo al his other Metallique deui≈øes and Inuentions, heere contained in the Patent, or Priuiledge of Metallica.

Secondly the con≈øideration of thinges in the like nature with it, are good inducements to per≈øwade vs well of this proiect, for Brickmaking, Brewing, Dying, Ca≈øting of Bra≈ø≈øeworkes, &c. were (not many yeares ≈øince) done altogether with the fuell of wood and Charcoale; in ≈øtead whereof Sea-coale is now v≈øed as effectually and to as good v≈øe and purpo≈øe. Againe (that which is ≈øomewhat neerer the marke) the Black≈ømith long agone forged all his Iron with Char-coale (as in ≈øome places where they are cheape they continue this cour≈øe ≈øtill) but the≈øe many yeares ≈ømall Sea-coale hath, and doth ≈øerue the turne, as well and ≈øufficiently. Adde heerevnto, that very lately by a wind-Furnace, greene gla≈ø≈øe, for windowes, is made as well with Pit-coale at Winche≈øter hou≈øe in Southwarke as it is done in other places with much wa≈øt & con≈øuming
of infinite ≈øtore of Billetts and other Woodfuell.

Thirdly the Inuention hath already experimented and made tryall of the cheife particular meanes and In≈øtruments of diuers cheape waies of making of Irons in reall and ≈øub≈øtantiall moddles to him-≈øelfe (though in ≈ømall things, according as his meanes would giue him leaue.) And this of his credit and hone≈øty he auoucheth and prote≈øteth: wherefore hee more confidently pre≈øumeth to worke the ≈øame effects in grander In≈øtruments and meanes of triall, after that hee hath receiued allowance of the dealers and a≈ø≈øi≈øtants for it.

Fourthly there can bee no doubt of performing the matter propounded, if the Inuentioner can but make, or cau≈øe Sea-coale to become as ≈øeruiceable for Metallique purpo≈øes as wood & Char-coale is: The art and ≈økill wherof con≈øi≈øteth cheifly in three points: The fir≈øt is to bring Earth-coale to that equallity of heat that Wood or Char-coale hath; That is to ≈øay, that it make neither hotter nor coulder
fier then the Wood or Char-coale doth: The ≈øecond meanes, is ≈øo to order and prepare Pit-coale, that all malignant proprieties, which are aver≈ø≈øe from the nature of Metallique ≈øub≈øtances, may bee extracted from it, or at lea≈øt de≈øtroyed in it: The third meanes is, the addition and infu≈øion of tho≈øe deficient proprieties, which as they are in Char-coale, ≈øo ought they to be found in Pit-coale.

Now this three-fold mi≈øtery and ≈øecret, the Author can certainly performe and atchieue, by the powerfull efficacie and meanes of his dexterous prerogatiue in≈øtruments, deui≈øed for this purpo≈øe; as more at large is ≈øhewed, both in this Treati≈øe, and in the Apendix, which very ≈øhortly ≈øhall come forth, and al≈øo ≈øhall be further confirmed and iu≈øtified by his dayly experiments and tryals, which hee will bee ready to ≈øhew to them whom they ≈øhall any wayes touch or concerne, or to them who are otherwi≈øe de≈øirous to a≈ø≈øi≈øt and deale for the experimenting and accompli≈øhing of the≈øe ≈øo worthy good bu≈øine≈ø≈øes. And then
al≈øo they ≈øhall know my purpo≈øe for Contracting and bargaining by word of mouth, as it is be≈øt fitting for priuate dealings and negotiatings.

And thus (hauing briefly touched the≈øe foure premi≈øed points) I conclude and ≈øhut vp this Preface of Metallica. Humbly and vnfeignedly be≈øeeching the Lord, who by his holy ≈øpirit in≈øpired * Bezaleel,
Exod. 31.1.2. Aholiab and * Hiram, with the light of Mechannicall Inuentions,2. Cro. 2.7.14. and in all manner of workeman≈øhip, for his effectuall ble≈ø≈øings in the≈øe our enterpri≈øes,Ni≈øi dom. aedificauerit. P≈øalm. 127 that that which was begun in his feare, may be pro≈øecuted & fully accompli≈øhed and built by his heauenly & helpful hands, to the glory of his name, and for the good well-fare and emolument of the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, the Church and the Politicall e≈øtate wherein wee liue. Amen.

div.head: CAPVT. 1. The Tran≈øcript of his Maie≈øties Indenture.
div.p: Reader.

AS I vnder≈øtand, you haue promi≈øed and couenanted in your Pattent more fully and euidently to expre≈øse and enlarge in a Printed treati≈øe, to be called Metallica, euery point and part of your priuiledged bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, to the intent that the Reader might the better conceiue and iudge of the Inuentions propounded, and might the ≈øooner al≈øo bee induced to a≈øsi≈øt, and ≈øet forward, ≈øo good and worthy workes: First therefore I demand of you by what name and appellation you entitle that generall head, vnder the which you reduce and comprehend all the ≈øeuerall Arts and Inuentions of your Pattent.

Author. The generall, that comprehendeth all the other perticular Inuentions, is called Metallica, which is a word deriued and deduced from the Greeke and
Latin words Metallon, and Metallum, which ≈øignifie, in Engli≈øh, Mettles, which properly are Minerall ≈øub≈øtances, digged and taken out of the earth, of which ≈øort, are Iron, Lead, Tin, Copper, Bra≈ø≈øe, Gold, and Siluer, &c.

R. 2. Doth your Pattent of Metallica, onely containe the making of mettles by the meanes of Sea-coale and Pit-coale, and with your other Metallicall in≈øtruments which you haue deui≈øed for that purpo≈øe.

A. His Maie≈øties gratious grant is very large and ample, for it doth not onely comprehend and priuiledge the making of all kinde of mettles, after the manner pre≈øcribed, but al≈øo equally authorizeth and licen≈øeth any other Mechanick inuentions comprehended vnder the generall definition of Metallica which is mentioned in the Schedules or Manu≈øcript treati≈øe annexed to the Pattent, which Schedules haue the ≈øame force and validitie as his Maie≈øties Indenture it ≈øelfe.

R. 3. Then that I may certainely know and vnder≈øtand the extent of your priuiledge, repeate, I pray you, word by word, the definition of Metallica, as it is written in the ≈øaid Schedules, annexed to your Pattent.

A. Metallica mentioned in the petition, is thus defined. Metallica is an Art or Inuention, ≈øhewing how diuer≈øe things and Materials, now made and atteined vnto, in a very chargeable ≈øort, after the ordinary way, may be made and atteined to after a more cheaper manner, and as with the helpe of common in≈øtruments: ≈øo more e≈øpecially by diuer≈øe new deui≈øed
Metallicall in≈øtruments and meanes.
From the≈øe Metallicall in≈øtruments, the Art is generally called Metallica.

R. 4. This ≈øummary definition giueth mee ≈øome generall light and vnder≈øtanding into your bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, but that I may bee the more fully ≈øatisfied, I pray you rehear≈øe al≈øo the tenour of his Maie≈øties grant, as it is vnder the broad ≈øeale of England.

THIS Indenture made, the xxix. day of February, in the yeares of the Reigne of our Soueraigne Lord Iames, by the grace of God, King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, defender of the faith, &c. of England, France and Ireland the ninth, & of Scotland the xlv. Betwene our ≈øaid Soueraigne Lord, of the one party, and Simon Sturteuant Gentleman of the other party. WHEREAS the ≈øaid Simon Sturteuant, by long his ≈øtudy & great charge, hath atteined vnto diuer≈øe new exact Mechanick Arts, My≈øteries, Waies and Secrets of his own Inuention, whereby all kind of mettles, works, and other things and materialls, as namely Irons, Steeles, Leads, Tins, Coppers, Bra≈ø≈øes, and ≈øuch like. Secondly all kind of Metalique concoctions, as Sand-mettles, A≈øh-mettles, Ammels, and ≈øuch like. Thirdly, all kinde of Burnt-earths, as Tiles, Pauing-≈øtones, Bricks, and ≈øuch like. Fourthly all kind of Pre≈ø-wares, as Pre≈øt-tiles, Pre≈øt-bricks, Pre≈øt-monions,
Pre≈øt-≈øtones and ≈øuch like, with diuer≈øe other things and materials now made after the ordinarie cour≈øe, with Wood-fewell and Char-coale, may be a≈øwell made, wrought, and effected, as the ≈øaid Simon Sturteuant affirmeth, with Sea-coale, Pit-coale, Earth-coale, and Bru≈øh-fewell, whereby the Woods now generally wa≈øted, in all the chiefe wood-land countries of this realme of England by Iron milnes, and ≈øuch other Metallicall Furnaces and hearths, may be pre≈øerued from the great con≈øumption thereof, and ≈øaued from like inconuenience in other his Maie≈øties dominions, all which premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øo by this new Inuention to be made, the ≈øaid Simon Sturteuant hath vndertaken, ≈øhall be in ≈øub≈øtance and for v≈øe as ≈øufficient and as good as the other like Materialls now made and wrought with the chargeable and exce≈ø≈øiue wa≈øte of Wood and Char-cole. AND whereas al≈øo the ≈øaid Simon Sturteuant, for the better making, working, effecting, beating, burning, melting and effecting, the ≈øaid mettals, workes, things, and Materialls, by and wth Sea-coale, Pit-coale, Earth-coale, and
Bru≈øh-fewell, hath by his ≈øaid Inuention and skill, inuented diuers Furnaces, hearths, te≈øts, tooles, engins, milnes, and other in≈øtruments and meanes, new, and of his owne Inuention, neuer heretofore v≈øed or put in practi≈øe by any other. A. It appeareth out of the fir≈øt Section of the Schedules, annexed to the Patent, that the doctrine of Metallica cannot di≈øtinctly be knowne or Methodically expre≈ø≈øed, except that the art which pre≈øcribeth precepts, general to all arts and Inuentions, called Heuretica, be fir≈øt precognized.
R. 7. Define therefore breefely Heuretica.
A. Heuretica is the Art of Inuentions, teaching how to find out new, and to iudge of the old.
R. 8. What deui≈øion is there for Heuretica?
A. The doctrine of Inuentions hath two parts Reall and Technick.

A. Reall is the fir≈øt Part of Heuretica, which treateth of the In≈øtruments and Reall things, which belong to the Inuentions.

A. The Reall part ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe into two branches, whereof the fir≈øt is called Organick, and the other Emporeuticall or Polecall.
R. 11. Define the Organick part.
A. The organick is a part of Heuretica, which ≈øetteth downe the meanes and In≈øtruments, whereby the work of Art, intended, is brought forth, made and effected,
R. 12. Define the Emporeuticall or Poleck part.
A. The Emporeutick is an Organick part of Heuretica, which treateth of the worke of the art, which are commodities and wares for v≈øe and ≈øale, wherby profit is rai≈øed.

Note al≈øo, that Emporeuticks, being things artificiall, are al≈øo fitly called materialls, but if they be naturall, they are called things accquired by the art. So fi≈øh and foule are the Emporeutick things, acquired by the art of fi≈øhing and fouling, but lead and Iron are Emporeutick Materials made & wrought by Metallicque art.
R. 13. Define the Technick part.

A. The Technick is that habituall part of Heuretica, which treateth of the dexterous habit and faculty wherewith all the Artizands are to be quallified and endowed, who are apointed to make the Emporeutick workes of Inuentions,

div.head: CAP. 4. Another partition of Heuretica and an Inuention Mechanick defined.
div.p: R.
14 WHat other diui≈øion is there for Heuretica?
A Heuretica in re≈øpect of the worke intended is diuided into two parts, namely, into the Scientiffick part and Mechanick part.
R. 15. Define the Scientiffick part.

A. The Scientiffick is that part of Heuretica which pre≈øcribeth prceepts generall to all liberall arts, the end of which Arts, is cheefely Science or knowledge and not any reall vi≈øible worke, or ≈øen≈øible thing.
R. Define the Mechanick part.
A. The Mechanick part is that part of Heuretica which pre≈øcribeth precepts generall to all illiberall arts, the end of which arts is cheefly a reall vi≈øible work or ≈øen≈øible thing.
And the Inuention in this kind is called an Inuention Mechanick.
R. 16. Define therefore an Inuention Mechanick.
A. A Mechanick Inuention is the art of the Inuentor, which by effectuall In≈øtruments and meanes bringeth forth ≈øome new vi≈øible or ≈øen≈øible worke good and profitable to the common-wealth.

So the Inuention of printing is the ≈økill and art of Fau≈øtus Guttenbergius, which mi≈øtery (by the effectual deui≈øed means of the Pre≈ø≈øe, the Incke, the Characters and paper) bringeth forth impre≈ø≈øions and Bookes, which Mechanick workes are profitable and good for mans v≈øe.

Where note, that, Fir≈øt the Mechanick Art, ≈øecondly the In≈øtruments and meanes, thirdly the worke of the art, made by tho≈øe In≈øtruments, and meanes, are all called Mechanicks, and are all Inuentions in re≈øpect of the Author that deui≈øed them.
R. 17. Expre≈ø≈øe further euery word and clau≈øe of this definition, to the intent that I may the better vnder≈øtand them.

A. Your de≈øire ≈øhall bee ≈øati≈øfied. Fir≈øt then to ≈øpeake of the thing defined, you mu≈øt note that any other deuice, cour≈øe or way which bringeth forth no externall or Materiall worke, are al≈øo in re≈øpect of the Inuentor tearmed Inuentions.

So the fir≈øt di≈øcouery of the we≈øt Indies by Columbus, (in re≈øpect of him) is fitly called his Inuention, and the turning point of Nauigation called the Cape of bona Speran√ßa is Gaymus his inuention the like may be ≈øaid of fretum Magellanicum, and fretum Dauies, which although they are laudable Inuentions, di≈øcouered by ingenious & venturous per≈øons, yet cannot they be ≈øaid to be Mecanicks. becau≈øe they produce or leaue behind them Mechanick work, nor had any Mechanick in≈øtruments made by hands of man directly,
and of purpo≈øe for the performance of them, for the≈øe Mechanicks are onely propper to the≈øe kinds of inuentions which wee treate of.
R. 18. Wherefore call you an inuention a Mechanick Arte.

A. To put a di≈øtinction betweene the≈øe inuentions Mechanicall, and other inuentions of the liberall Arts and Sciences, of which ≈øort are Logick, Rhetorick, Grammer, and the Mathematicall ≈øciences, all which had their fir≈øt Authours and Inuentors.
R. 19. Wherfore ≈øay you the art of Inuentioner.
A. To ≈øhew that there is no Inuention without relation to the Inuentioner.
R. 20. Why then it ≈øeemeth that all Arts, ≈øciences, my≈øteries, trades, crafts, things and deui≈øes, which are now extant in the common-wealth, are, and may bee called Inuentions.

A. Yea verily ≈øo they may, if wee re≈øpect the Inuentioner, and fir≈øt Authors of them, but if we re≈øpect the per≈øons that v≈øe and put in practize the ≈øaid Inuentions at the ≈øecond hand, as we ≈øay, ≈øuch as are the Artificers, Trade≈ømen and others that make the ≈øaid Mechanick workes, in re≈øpect of the≈øe ≈øecondary per≈øons they are called Arts, Trades, Crafts, Syences, Mi≈øteries, Occupations, Profe≈ø≈øions, and ≈ølightes, &c.

So the printing, as al≈øo the Pre≈ø≈øe, the Paper, the Characters, together with the works done, as impre≈ø≈øions, bookes, and vollumes, in re≈øpect of Fau≈øtus are his Inuention, but in re≈øpect of Printers, which now

R. 21. To what v≈øe ≈øerueth the knowledge of this.

A. This fitly ≈øerueth to refute the erronious folly of ≈øuch ≈øhallow ≈øimple per≈øons, which cannot abide any new inuentioÃÑ, which this our age bringeth forth, they vtterly di≈øta≈øte both the proiects and Inuentors, they for≈øooth (as they ≈øay) will giue no a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, they will not meddle nor deale with them, they will not v≈øe their new worke, though neuer ≈øo good and profitable, nay they ≈øay more, after their fond fa≈øhion, it will neuer prooue good, or come to pa≈ø≈øe, with a hundred ≈øuch like ≈øpeeches, tending to the di≈øprai≈øe both of the Inuentioner, and of things deui≈øed by him, but being demanded for their rea≈øon, they haue none to alleadge, except onely a womans rea≈øon, like vnto that of the Epigrammati≈øt:
Non amo te Volu≈øi, non po≈ø≈øum dicere quare,

But if the≈øe men, who ≈øo much ≈øpurne at inuentions, did well con≈øider, that all ancient Mechanick trades, occupations, profe≈ø≈øions and workes, which now are in v≈øe in the common-wealth, were new at the fir≈øt, and had their beginning and infancy, and how they

If I ≈øay they did well, con≈øider and ponder this, they would not be ≈øo auer≈øe and bitter again≈øt laudable, and good proiects, brought forth now a dayes, for with as good rea≈øon they might enueigh again≈øt printing, ≈øhipping, milning and buildings, again≈øt the ordinary waies of making of ≈øalts, alloms, coppre≈ø≈øes, and ≈øaultpeeter, again≈øt the trade and art of making of hats, and knit-≈øtockings, ≈øhooes, bootes, and apparell, again≈øt the art and trade of making of ≈øaddles, carts, ploughes, harrowes, and again≈øt the art of melting, founding, and ca≈øting of mettles, of forging, hammering, and battering of irons, bra≈ø≈øe, peuters, ≈øiluer, and gould; and finally again≈øt all other trades, occupations, vocations, and profe≈ø≈øions in the common-wealth, as ≈øo ba≈øely to regard and e≈øteeme the proffitable and new inuentions of our daies. Againe, in ≈øcorning, and contemning of profitable bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of late inuention, they ≈øet them≈øelues not onely again≈øt man, but al≈øo again≈øt the ≈øpirit of God, who is the authour of the ≈øaid gifts, and fir≈øt worke of them in man, as it is expre≈ø≈øely taught in the 31. of Exodus: in the example of two worthy inuentioners, and artificers, the wordes of the text are the≈øe. Behold (≈øaith God to Mo≈øes) I haue called by name Bezaleele the ≈øonne of Vri, the ≈øonne of Hur, of the tribe of Iuda, whom I haue filled with the ≈øpirit of God in wi≈øedome and

div.head: CAP. 5. Tran≈øient instrumentall meanes.
div.p: R. 22. In the definition of the Organicke part, you ≈øay that the worke is produced by in≈øtruments and meanes, I would therefore know of you, how many kindes of in≈øtruments and meanes there are to effect a new bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.
A. The Organick things for the effecting of a new Inuention are of two ≈øorts, Permanent or Tran≈øient.
R. 23. De≈øcribe the Tran≈øient In≈øtrument and meanes.

A In≈øtruments and means are ≈øaid to be Tran≈øient, when in re≈øpect of their v≈øe, they ≈øerue but once for that imployment for which they were appointed, ≈øo fuell and oare are Tran≈øient, becau≈øe they wa≈øt and con≈øume in that Materiall which they make.
R. 24. How many kindes are there of this Tran≈øient ≈øort
A. Two: Efficientall, or Materiall.
R. 25. De≈øcribe the Efficientall In≈øtruments.

A. Efficientall are ≈øuch Tran≈øient In≈øtruments and meanes as vani≈øh and con≈øume away in their fir≈øt v≈øe, whil≈øt they are performing their operation and efficiency to produce the pretended Mechanick work, as namely the fuell or fiering in euery bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.
R. 26. De≈øcribe the Materiall In≈øtruments.

A. Materiall, are ≈øuch Tran≈øient In≈øtruments and meanes wherof the In≈øtruments con≈øi≈øt and are made, not vading or vani≈øhing away, but remaining tran≈øformed or altered in the ≈øub≈øtance of the thing effected, as namely the ≈øtuffe and matter of euery Mechanick in≈øtrument.

div.head: CAPVT. 6. Permanent In≈øtruments and meanes.
div.p: R.
27. I vnder≈øtand well the Tran≈øient in≈øtruments, with their ≈øeuerall kindes, pray you de≈øcribe the permanent.

A. In≈øtruments and meanes are ≈øaid to be permanent when as they ≈øerue to performe their operations
diuer≈øe times (to wit) in this thing, in that thing, and in many others, of this ≈øort are all tooles in euery trade, all kilnes, furnaces, ouens, hearthes, in euery trade. If we re≈øpect the fir≈øt making and creation of permanent in≈øtruments, then mu≈øt we con≈øider their efficientall, and materiall meanes al≈øo.
R. 28. How many kindes are their of this ≈øort.

A. Two, for the≈øe permanent meanes, are either per≈øonall, as namely the workeman and artificers in euery action; or el≈øe imper≈øonall, of which ≈øort are all other in≈øtruments of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.
R. 29. How many ≈øorts of workemen are there for euery inuention.
A. Two, primary, and annuall, primarie as the inuentioner to guide, and artificers to make, the annuall are the daily workemen which make the Mechanicke.
R. 30. How many artificers are nece≈ø≈øarie for the prymarie, and fir≈øt foundation of mechanicke inuentions.

A. The≈øe ≈øub≈øequent are mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie, as namely; Ioyners, Carpenters, Smithes, Brickelayers, Ma≈øons, whereunto in ≈øeuerall inuentions, diuer≈øe other Artificers are to be added, as occa≈øion ≈øerueth, as Shoomakers, Glouers, Bellowes-makers &c.
R. 31. How many ≈øorts of annuall workemen are nece≈ø≈øarie for the yearely managing of an inuention.

A. Two, the mai≈øter and ouer≈øeer, or his apprentices, or ≈øeruants, which make the mechanicke worke, And ≈øecondly, the repairationers, which maintaine and mend the in≈øtruments and meanes which at the
fir≈øt they made and formed.
R. 32. What di≈øtribution haue you for imper≈øonall in≈øtruments.

A. The imper≈øonall in≈øtruments, are either generall or ≈øpeciall, the generall is the worke-hou≈øe wherein other in≈øtruments doe their operations, worke and imployment, and vnder this head we comprehend the ground, place, yard, or roome, where the Mechanicke bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is wrought or done. The ≈øpeciall imper≈øonall in≈øtruments, are all other imper≈øonall in≈øtruments, be≈øides the worke-hou≈øe or place. Among≈øt which imper≈øonall in≈øtruments furnacing may here bee briefely touched as being a nece≈ø≈øarie in≈øtrument in mo≈øt inuentions.
R. 33. How define you a furnace.

A. Diuer≈øe, as namely all kinde of ouens, lamps, ≈øtoues, kilnes, hearths, all which we generally comprehend vnder the name of Furnacing.

div.head: CAP. 7. In≈øtruments and meanes procured and meerely opperatiue, monies and charges of a bu≈øine≈øse.
div.p: R.
35. WHat other di≈øtribution haue you of in≈øtruments, and meanes of a bu≈øines, in re≈øpect of charges.
A. Organicke meanes of a Mechanicke, are either procuring, or meerely opperatiue.

R. 36. What is generally to be knowne and con≈øidered, concerning the monies to be disbur≈øed in a bu≈øines.
A. Monies or charges of a bu≈øines, are either primarie and once impended, or el≈øe annuall, and at certaine times to be renewed.
R. 37. What differeÃÑces are their of primary monies.
A. Primary monies are either disbur≈øements about the fir≈øt foundation, or about the tryall.
R. 38. What call you fundamentall charges.

A. Charges of foundation are all ≈øuch primary monies which are to be disbur≈øed at the fir≈øt erection or ≈øetting vp of a new bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, or of grand Mechanickes, in ≈øome one conuenient place, whereby a worke-hou≈øe is furni≈øhed with all permanent nece≈ø≈øary tooles and in≈øtruments.
R. What call you charges of tryall.
A. Charges of tryall are the primary monies which are be≈øtowed and disbur≈øed about the tryall and experimenting of an inuention or new bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.
R. 40. Wherein con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe charges of tryall.

A. The triall monies are to be disbur≈øed fir≈øt about the Theoricke in≈øtruments, and meanes of an inuention, that is the whole de≈øcription of an inuention. Whether it be by way of manu≈øcript writings, or printed treati≈øes.
Secondly, about the moddles of an inuention, whether they be ≈øuperficiall, or reall, motionall or directionall.
And la≈øtly about the erection and foundation of the Protopla≈øt, vnto which al the other grand mechanickes are to be conformed.
R. 41. Concerning the charge of tryall, what is fitte≈øt for an Inuentioner to demaund of them that are willing to deale in a new bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

It is the wi≈øe≈øt, ≈øafe≈øt, and mo≈øt credible cour≈øe for the Inuentioner, not to aske vnder-hand, whereby he ≈øhall be driuen to repaire to them againe the ≈øecond time, but rather at the fir≈øt let him aske and agree for more monie, and not for le≈ø≈øe then will ≈øerue the turne.
R. 42. What other chiefe rules ought an Inuentioner carefully to ob≈øerue in the practi≈øe and tryall of any new inuention.
A. That he may make tryall and put in practi≈øe his new deui≈øe and inuention with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and to purpo≈øe, let him alwaies well remember the≈øe ≈øub≈øequent rules.

1. Make things ≈øtronger, then that exact ≈øtrength
which the thing is to haue.
2. Make things greater then that exact greatne≈ø≈øe which the thing is to haue.
3. And therefore make thinges longer, broader, thicker and wider, then that exact length, breadth, thickne≈ø≈øe and widene≈ø≈øe that the thing is to haue.

7. Yet if the Inuentioner can make the thing in the exact truth, then let him do it accordingly, for this is alwaies lea≈øt chargeable.
R. 43. In the fir≈øt triall of things can the Inuentioner perfectly hit on the exactne≈ø≈øe of euery particular in≈øtrument and means belonging to the new bu≈øines.

A. The Vndertakers and dealers are to expect ≈øome lo≈ø≈øe in triall of new bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, be the Inuentioner neuer ≈øo perfect in his Theorick; for although he do his be≈øt indeauor, and giue perfect directions to his workmen and Artificers, yet they will often faile and erre in their worke, by which meanes the in≈øtrument being experimented and put to triall, becometh

R. 44. What call you the Annuall charges of an inuention.

A. Annuall, are ≈øuch monyes which from time to time, vpon occa≈øion, are be≈øtowed after the fir≈øt Plantation vppon the repairing, maintaining, and continuing the ≈øaid primary in≈øtruments belonging to the ≈øaid new bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CAPVT. 8. Inuentions intermixtand pure moddle, Protopla≈øt and grand Mechanick defined.
div.p: YOu haue handled the doctrine of the generall meanes and In≈øtruments of Inuentions, proceed I pray you to ≈øpeake of the differences and diuers kindes of Inuentions, and Fir≈øt therefore I de≈øire to know.
R. 45. How many ≈øorts or kindes of Inuention are there being compared or con≈øidered one with another?

A. Two, An Inuention is either pure or intermixt, an Inuention is ≈øaid to bee pure and entire within it ≈øelfe, when as none of the parts e≈ø≈øentiall are common to any other Inuention for the ≈øame v≈øe.
Intermixt when as ≈øome of the parts are found in ≈øome other former inuention.

So a Windmill is an intermixt Inuention, becau≈øe ≈øome of the partes, as namely the Milne ≈øtones, the rong-wheeles and the Cogg-wheeles were fir≈øt extant in awater-milne or hor≈øe-milne and quernes.
But a hand-Querne was a pure and ≈øimple Inuention becau≈øe none of the parts there of were formerly extant in any other Mechanick.
And ≈øo printing is a pure and ≈øimple Inuention, becau≈øe none of the e≈ø≈øentiall parts thereof were taken from any former Inuention, where they were applied to the ≈øame v≈øe.

Where note that the common parts of an intermixt Inuention are to be e≈øteemed as propper and peculiar to the ≈øame Inuention, when as they are conioyned and mixed in with other new things In≈øtruments and meanes, which are the e≈ø≈øentiall parts of the new deui≈øe.
R. 46. What other di≈øtribution haue you of an inuention in re≈øpect of magnitude.

A. In re≈øpect of greatne≈ø≈øe or quantity, there are
three ≈øorts of inuentions, namely the Moddle, the Protopla≈øt, and the grand Mechanick.
R. 47. De≈øcribe the Moddle.

A. The Moddle is a Mechanick, which onely repre≈øenteth and decyphereth, in ≈øome little platforme, the true part and lineaments of the Mechanick inuention, beeing in≈øufficient to yeeld any Emporeutick v≈øe of the inuention.
So the Moddle of a winde-milne, repre≈øenteth the failes and other parts of Fabrick and ≈øtructure, but grindeth no corne.
Where note, that ≈øome times the moddle is to be made greater then the Mechanick, e≈øp ecially in ≈ømall curious things, as in a watch, and ≈øuch like.
R. 48. How many ≈øorts of moddles are there.
A. Two, Superficiall and Reall.

The Superficiall de≈øcribeth onely the parts and line aments in paper, bordes or pa≈øt-bords, by limning, drawing, or painting, ≈øhewing no action or opperation, nor corporall dimen≈øions of the parts.

A Reall moddle is that which ≈øheweth euery part of the greater Mechanick, in a true and liuely (though little) proportion, hauing his parts fitted for motion, action, or opperation: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is not ≈øo effectuall or fully v≈øe-full, beeing onely repre≈øentatiue, as was touched before.
So a little ≈øhip, which you haue hanging vp in a marchants hou≈øe, is the Reall moddle of a grand ≈øhip or ≈øea ve≈ø≈øell, becau≈øe it repre≈øenteth euery part and action thereof.
R. 49. What is the principall v≈øe of a Reall Moddle.

A. The cheefe≈øt v≈øe of a reall moddle is that the Inuention may thereby more perfectly and exactly direct both him≈øelfe, and al≈øo guide his workmen for the fini≈øhing of any grander Mechanick of the ≈øame kind, thereby the better to produce and bring forth the Theorick conceiued in his mind into the grand Reall Inuention.

So the v≈øe of a ≈ømall reall moddle of a Wind-milne ≈øerueth uery fitly to direct both the Inuentor him≈øelfe and likewi≈øe all his Carpenters and other workmen, to proceed infallibly to build and ≈øet vp a reall and grand windmilne intended to be made.
R. 50. How many ≈øorts of reall moddles are there.
A. There are two ≈øorts, for either they are meerely directionall or al≈øo motionall.

Directionall is that moddle which is made only to direct and guide the Artificer in the dimen≈øions of all the parts, as al≈øo for to direct them for the kinds of the matter and the ≈øtuffe that they are to haue to make the engin intended.
R. 51. What is the fitte≈øt and cheape≈øt ≈øtuffe to make a directionall moddle of.
A. Pa≈øt-boordes and reedes are the fitte≈øt either for Iron-works or woodworks, wherof the Pa≈øt-bords are in ≈øtead of boordes, plancks and bed-≈øides.

And the Reeds are to repre≈øent round Cylindriack timber, as al≈øo other ≈øquare timber, as namely ≈øingle
quarters, double quarters, puncheons, rafters, tran≈øummes &c.
So that of the≈øe the Inuentioner may fitly and ≈øpeedily make and contriue the fabricke and ≈øtructure of any directionall moddle.
R. 52. What call you a motionall moddle.

A. A motionall is that moddle Reall which is made compleat in euery part, hauing his true v≈øe, opperation and motion, as in the grander Mechanickes, yet hauing no Emporeuticke commodity, but onely for ≈øhew and tryall, and not for ≈øale and v≈øe.
There are three degrees in this motionall moddle, the meane moddle, the le≈ø≈øer then the meane, the greater then the meane.

The meane moddle is a motionall, which hath his magnitude and greatne≈ø≈øe betweene the other extreames, being the lea≈øt chargeable to be made. And it is alwaies greater then the le≈ø≈øer motionall, and le≈ø≈øer then the greater motion all: and there is but one meane modle to be found in the progre≈ø≈øioÃÑ of the ≈øame degres

Where note that it belongeth principally to the Inuentioners skil and care to ≈øet forth the dimen≈øions and parts of his moddle, intended with the lea≈øt expence of charges that may be, and in the ea≈øie≈øt and redie≈øt manner for his workemen to vnder≈øtand and imitate, or el≈øe he hitteth not vpon the meane moddle, but vpon ≈øome other extreame.
R. 53. Define the Protopla≈øt.

A. The Protopla≈øt is an Inuention mechanick which fir≈øt is ≈øet vp of that kind, and ≈øeruing to profitable
Emporeuticke v≈øes, hauing all the principall parts, actions, and perfections, which all other ≈øub≈øequent grand Mechanicks ought to haue of the ≈øame kinde, which afterward are to be made and framed by it.

So the fir≈øt windmilne that the inuentioner euer ≈øet vp to grinde corne was the Protopla≈øt and example from whence all other wind-milnes ≈øprange and were deriued, the like may bee ≈øaid of the fir≈øt of euery kinde of Mechanicke, as of Faustus his fir≈øt Printing Pre≈ø≈øe, &c.
R. 54. Define a grand Mechanicke.

A. The grand Mechanicke, is that which is ≈øet vp after the forme and tipe of his Protopla≈øt, for the ≈øame v≈øe and purpo≈øe, onely differing from the Protopla≈øt in greatne≈ø≈øe, or with ≈øome profitable additions which later experience hath taught.

So the Windmilnes in More-fields are Mechanicks of that kinde of inuention, for they are builded after the Archerype of the Protopla≈øt which the inuentor fir≈øt inuented and erected, ≈øeruing to the ≈øame v≈øe of grinding of corne; they differ onely in this, they haue a deui≈øe called the Crampe, which will ≈øodenly ≈øtay (in the face of the ≈øtorme) the violent motion or circumgyration of the wheeles, vntill the ≈øales are taken downe or fardled vp.

div.head: CAP. 9. Innentions Heterocre≈øious and Homocre≈øious, primatiue, and deriuatiue, defined.
div.p: Reader.
55. VVHat other di≈øtribution haue you of a Mechanick inuention, con≈øidered one with an other.
A. Inuentions con≈øidered compa≈øatiuely one with another, haue two differences, for they are eyther Heterocre≈øious, or el≈øe Homocre≈øious.

Heterocre≈øious, are inuentions which produce different Mechanick workes, wares and commodities. So milning and ≈øhipping are two Heterocre≈øious inuentions, becau≈øe the worke of the one is meale or flower, and the worke of the other is carriage or tran≈øportage.
R. 56. Define Homocre≈øious Inuentions.
A. Homocre≈øious inuentions, are ≈øuch which produce and bring forth Emporeuticall workes for the ≈øame v≈øe.
So a hor≈øe-milne, a water milne, a wind-milne are Homocre≈øious, becau≈øe they all grinde flower, though after different manner and wayes.
R. 57. What di≈øtribution haue you for Homocre≈øious.

A. An Inuention Homocre≈øious, is either primatiue or deriuatiue, the primatiue is that which was the
fir≈øt in v≈øe in the world of the ≈øame kinde.

So a Pe≈øtle and a Morter is a primatiue inuention, becau≈øe it was fir≈øt v≈øed for to beat and bru≈øe corne into meale and powder, and at this day it is ≈øtill v≈øed to grinde eaten grotes, but a hand-querne, a hor≈ø-milne, a winde-milne, and a water-milne, are Inuentions deriuatiue, all which were found out in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of time, long after the pe≈øtle and the mortar.
R. 58. Giue ≈øome other illu≈øtrious examples of primatiue and deriuatiue inuentions.

A. In matters of literature, the Art of writing with the pen, is a worthy primatiue inuention, both for writing and reading, found out by Mo≈øes, that learned Leuite and thrice holy Prophet, the deriuatiue inuention, whereof is Printing, a far more exqui≈øite mi≈øtery deui≈øed of late yeares by Fau≈øtus Guttenbergius.
So in husbandry the Spade, the Rake, and Shouell, was a worthy primatiue inuention of Adam, for the tillage and ≈øowing of the ground, according to that ancient and old prouerbe.

But the Plough and the Harrow are their deriuatiue inuentions, which for the v≈øes of husbandry doe farre exceed them, for by them more worke of tillage of the ground may be done in one day with the ≈øame charge, then could be done by their primatiue inuentions in twenty dayes.

Againe the Barrow which carrieth burdens from places is a primatiue inuention, but the Cart with wheeles is a far more excellent deriued Mechanick, becau≈øe it carrieth more in one day, then the primatiue can doe in ten dayes with the ≈øame charges.

And this Inuention of round wheeles to draw and carry loades with a ≈ømall ≈øtrength vndoubtedly was grounded on this Geometricall axiom, Circulus tangit planum vnico puncto, for if the wheeles ≈øhould haue beene made ≈øquare, trencher wi≈øe, or in any other poly-angle, forty hor≈øes would not ≈øo ea≈øily draw them beeing laden, as two doth now with both ≈øpeed and ea≈øe. And thus much for the example of primatiue and deriuatiue Inuentions.
Where note, that the deriuatiue mu≈øt alwayes bee of a greater v≈øe, and doe more good in the common wealth, then the primatiue, or el≈øe it is not to bee receiued.

Note al≈øo, if there be many deriuatiues in the ≈øame kinde, the latter inuention mu≈øt alwayes better the former, and beeing all of them compared and rancked with their primatiue, they make an Inuentionall progre≈ø≈øion, one exceeding an other, in goodne≈ø≈øe and v≈øe, among≈øt which, the la≈øt of all ought to bee the be≈øt, and is therefore called the Eumechanick in the progre≈ø≈øion of that kinde.
R. 59. Giue ≈øome examples of Inuentionall progre≈ø≈øion.

A. I will ≈øatisfie your de≈øire, and fir≈øt in matter of husbandry, for the making of bread, which mainteineth
the life of man, there is a progre≈ø≈øion of the≈øe fiue Inuentions.
Fir≈øt the Mortar, ≈øecondly the Hand-querne, thirdly the Hor≈øe-milne, fourthly the Water-milne, fiftly the Winde-milne.
To which if we adde the inuention of the Plegnick Milne, it maketh vp the ≈øixt, and is the Eumechanick of that kinde.

Secondly, in ho≈øe or ≈øtockings, there is a progre≈ø≈øion of three, cloth or ker≈øey ≈øtockings, which were fir≈øt in v≈øe: Secondly in knit ≈øtockings with Needles: Thirdly, and la≈øtly, in knit ≈øtockings with loome, which is a late Inuention of one Mai≈øter Lee.

Thirdly, in ve≈ø≈øels of drinking, there is a large progre≈ø≈øion. For fir≈øt, to pretermit the cup of the hand, out of which Adam and Gedeons three hundred Souldiers dranke, Iudg. 7.6. There is ≈øecondly the earthen Pitcher, which the Samaritane woman had at the Well: and the third roome came vp the v≈øe of the black Leather Iacks, an ancient drinking ve≈ø≈øell of our natiue countrymen, and the fourth place ≈øprung vp the v≈øe of Tankards and Wodden Kans, in the fift out of Hornes, in the ≈øixt Silues, Gould, greene-Gla≈ø≈øe, Venice gla≈ø≈øe, and Peuter.
All inuentions, for the mo≈øt part, of latter times, are deriuatiue, & the Inuentioners are to make choice of this kinde, and needeth the le≈ø≈øe to ≈øpend his time about any primatiue deuice.

div.head: CAP. 10. Inuentions organicall and emporeuticall: The parts and adiuncts: The Theoricke and Practicke of an Inuention Organicall.
div.p: R.
60. VVhat other di≈øtribution is their of an inuention Mechanicke.
A. An inuention Mechanicke, in re≈øpect of v≈øe is either Organicall or Emporeuticall.
An Inuention Organicall is that artificiall fabricke or ≈øtructure compacted of all imper≈øonall in≈øtruments and meanes which make the Emporeuticke comodities.
So the windmilne con≈øidered in it ≈øelfe is the compact, ≈øtructure or fabricke, which comprehendeth all permanent in≈øtruments and meanes which produce, yeeld, and bring forth meale or flower.
But the flower and meale thus ground and made by the windemilne Engin is fitly called the inuention emporeuticall.
So likewi≈øe the whole ≈øtructure and complement of all the permanent, and imper≈øonall in≈øtruments, and meanes which make vp the Ferricall furnace, is termed the inuention.
R. 61. What differences haue you for the parts of an Inuention Organicall.
A. The parts of an inuention Organicall, are either e≈ø≈øentiall or ine≈ø≈øentiall, comon or peculiar Organicall.
But the earth-coale iron which is made by the ≈øaid complement, and panoply of in≈øtruments is fitly called the Emporeuticall inuention of the Author or Inuentor.
R. 62. De≈øcribe the e≈ø≈øentiall parts of an inuention Organicall.

A. The e≈ø≈øentiall part of an inuention Organicall is any maine and chiefe member, whereby the engin is well enabled to performe his worke and operation, which being lacking, the other parts of the engin become ineffectuall, and inoperatiue, for the producing the Emporeuticke intended.

So a windmilne con≈øi≈øteth of all hise≈ø≈øential parts, be≈øides his cro≈ø≈øe ≈øales is ineffectuall and not able to grinde corne, the like may be ≈øaid if it lacke a cogwheele, a ronge wheele, a milne-≈øtone, or any other e≈ø≈øentiall part.
R. 63. De≈øcribe an ine≈ø≈øentiall part of an Inuention Organicall.

A. An ine≈ø≈øentiall part is an additament, which indeede ≈øomewhat bettereth and helpeth the Inuention, when it is added to the maine complement of the Machin, or Engin, yet being lacking and not v≈øed, it taketh not away the opperation or worke of the inuention or engin: of this ≈øort, is the crampe of a windmilne, which is a very good and worthy addittament, found out by ≈øome ingenious Milner of late, and it is able to hold the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øales immoueable, euen in the very bla≈øt of a ≈øtorme.
Yet wind-milnes which haue not nor had not this later addition of the crampe doe daily grinde corne a≈øwell as other wind-milnes which are there withall furni≈øhed.

But in a ≈øtorme they are driuen to this inconuenience: that three or foure mu≈øt pre≈øently goe downe to turne their cro≈ø≈øe failes out of the winde, that they may take downe and fardle vp their ≈øailes.

So likewi≈øe the bra≈ø≈øe plate and the rouling girth are nece≈ø≈øarie and conuenient additions in the engin of the Printing Pre≈ø≈øe, and both of them were of late yeares fir≈øt deui≈øed (as it is ≈øaid) by one Mai≈øter Haruie an ingenious Printer in London.
Yet before they were added or v≈øed in the mi≈øtery of Printing, Fau≈øtus his inuention was ab≈øolute and compleate of it ≈øelfe.
R. 64 De≈øcribe the common parts of an inuention Organicall.
The common parts are ≈øuch as are borrowed from other trades, occupations and mi≈øteries formerly inuented and in v≈øe, and now adioyned and mixed in, among≈øt the new parts of the Inuention.
R. 65. What call you the peculiar parts of an inuention.
A. The peculiar parts are ≈øuch as are proper and of the e≈ø≈øence of the inuention, not being taken from any other Mechanicke, formerly in v≈øe.

So the ≈øayles, the milne-po≈øt, the ≈øpurs of a wind-milne are his peculiar parts, but the cogge-wheeles,
ronge-wheeles, and milne≈øtones are common parts as being a≈ø≈øumed and borrowed from the hor≈øe-milne and water-milne formerly in v≈øe.
R. 66. What differences haue you for the adiuncts of an inuention Organicall.
A. The adiuncts of an inuention Organicall haue the ≈øame differences, which the parts of an inuention had before.

For the adiuncts are either e≈ø≈øentiall or ine≈ø≈øentiall, common or peculiar, the nature and di≈øtinction of which differences may be ea≈øily conceiued and vnder≈øtood by the de≈øcriptions of the former ≈øeuerall parts.
R. 67. What other differences haue you for the adiuncts of an inuention Organicall.
A. The adiuncts of an inuention Organicall are al≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie or le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øarie.
Nece≈ø≈øarie adiuncts are all ≈øuch which of nece≈ø≈øitie are to be v≈øed for the producing of the intended Mechanicke.
And the le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øarie are all ≈øuch which bringes ≈øome ≈ømall helpe to make and bringe forth the Emporeuticke.
R. 68. What di≈øtribution haue you of an inuention Organicall.
A. An inuention is ≈øaid to haue a Theoricke or a Practicke.
R. 69. What call you Theoricke Inuention.

A. The Theoricke of an inuention is the declaration of the contents thereof by a plaine and familiar di≈øcription, and that either by manu≈øcript
writings or by printed treati≈øes.
R. 70. What Arguments are cheefe for the de≈øcription of an Inuention.
A. The arguments of the parts and adiuncts, or the Arguments of In≈øtruments and meanes.
R. 71. Do the parts, and adiuncts, and In≈øtruments, and meanes, expre≈ø≈øe diuers meanes.

A. No, for by parts and adiuncts are vnder≈øtood the ≈øelfe ≈øame things, which are meant by in≈øtruments and meanes, but yet in diuers and different re≈øpects: for they are called parts and adiuncts in re≈øpect that the Mechanick Engin ≈øub≈øi≈øteth & con≈øi≈øteth of them, but in re≈øpect of the Emporeutick, which is made by them, the ≈øaid partes and adiuncts are fitly called In≈øtruments and meanes.

So a printing Pre≈ø≈øe hath his ≈øeuerall parts, whervpon it doth con≈øi≈øt, as the ≈øcrew, the nut, the pare-tree and the cha≈øe, &c. it hath al≈øo his adiuncts belonging to it, as the Inck and the Inck-bals &c. which ≈øaid parts and adiuncts of the Pre≈ø≈øe con≈øidered, with the printed papers, bookes and impre≈ø≈øions which are the ≈øaleable Emporeutick workes. I ≈øay in this re≈øpect they are called In≈øtruments and meanes whereby printed Bookes are atteined vnto.
R 72. Define a practick of an Inuention.
A The practick of an Inuention is that which is made in reall parts and adiunct, according to the de≈øcription of the Theorick of an inuention.

So if you de≈øcribe an Iron furnace by euery part and adiunct which belongeth therunto, ≈øuch a di≈øcription
is called the Theorick of a Furnace, but afterward if you make a real Furnace, either of moddle, ≈øtuffe or of brick, clay, or earth, according to the de≈øcription & Theorick proportions, then ≈øuch a Furnace is called the practick of a Furnace, the like may be ≈øaid of any other Mechanick or Engin.
R. 73. What cannons haue you of an inuention in re≈øpect of the Theorick.
A. The Theorick of an Inuention is to be de≈øcribed by his parts and adiuncts that other mens labours and indeauors bee incroached vppon or fore≈øtalled thereby.

div.head: CAP. 11. An Inuention triable and vntriable conformable and inconformable, Royall and Coppy-hold.
div.p: R.
74 WHat other kindes or ≈øorts haue you of an Inuention.
A. An Inuention is two fould, An Inuention of di≈øcouery, or an inuention of experiment, or an Inuention is triable, or vntriable.
R. 75. What call you a triable Inuention.

A. A triable Iuuention is an inuention who≈øe worth and goodne≈ø≈øe cannot certainly appeare before trialls and experiments be made, not only in the moddles thereof, but al≈øo in the Protop la≈øt it ≈øelfe.
Of this ≈øort, are all the Inuentions Metallicall, compri≈øed in the Patent and al≈øo the Inuention called the Regi≈øter for generall commerce.
R. 76. Define an inuention vntriable.

A. An vntryable inuention is a new proiect or di≈øcouery, who≈øe worth and goodne≈ø≈øe requireth no tryals, but may bee iudged and di≈øcerned onely by the di≈øcription or declaration of the plot and proiect.

Of this ≈øort are all Monopolies, new cu≈øtomes, impo≈øts, taxations, ≈øub≈øidies, ≈øtatutes, with fines, and diuers other ≈øtate bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, di≈øcoueries and inuentions, which are ordinarily propounded or petitioned of his Maie≈øtie.
Of this ≈øort is Sepherica, a late inuention of the Authours, the proiect and contents whereof ≈øhall be handled in a treati≈øe called Sepherica.
R. 77. How many ≈øorts of tryable inuentions are there.
A. An inuention tryable is either conformeable or inconformeable.
R. 78. Define a conformeable inuention.

A. A conformeable inuention is an inuention tryable which reformeth and bettereth a former inuention (requiring but ≈øome ≈ømall and not chargeable alteration) after that the new is vnited to the ould.

So the Iron furnaces, fineries and chafferies may be much reformed and bettered with ≈ømall charges, hauing our Ferricall inuention vnited to them, and therefore the Ferricall inuention is fitly called a conformeable inuention.
R. 79. What Cannons or rules haue you for a conformeable inuention.

A. Conformeable inuention being priueledged is farre more beneficiall and commodious to the Pattentees & the dealers in that bu≈øines, theÃÑ an inconformable inuention, and the rea≈øon is becau≈øe that imediatly after the grand tryals are brought to pa≈ø≈øe and performed in the Protopla≈øt, they may choo≈øe whether they will be at any further charge, and yet they may rai≈øe pre≈øent rent and benefit by conforming of the former inuentions to the Protopla≈øt, and not at theirs, but onely at the charges of the owners of former works and inuentions.
R. 80. Define an inconformable inuention.

A. An inuention is ≈øaid to be inconformable who≈øe Protopla≈øt being erected and ≈øet vp, cannot be conformed to any former inuention in v≈øe, where by yearely profits of conformity may be rai≈øed without charges to the Pattentees and dealers.

So the pre≈ø≈øeware inuention maketh tiles and brickes, and all other clayworks, after a farre more gainefull and beneficiall manner then by the ordinary cour≈øe, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is an inconformable inuention, becau≈øe that the ordinary Arts of tilemaking and brick-making cannot bee conformed vnto the Pre≈ø≈øe-ware Protopla≈øt with ≈øome ≈ømall alterations and ≈ømall charges.
R. 81. What Cannons or Rules haue you of an inconformable inuention.

A. An inconformable inuention requireth a great ≈øtocke and great disbur≈øements for the Pattentees,
to lay out, a≈øwell for the Protaple≈øt as al≈øo for ≈øome two or three grander Mechanicks thereof.

Secondly an inconformable inuention after the erection and perfection of the Protopla≈øt in continewance of time, may rai≈øe great rents and fines by licences, lea≈øes and deui≈øes though no by pre≈øent conformity.
R. 82. What other di≈øtribution haue you for an inuention Mechanicke.
A. An inuention Mechanicke, is either priuiledged or vnpriuiledged, againe it is either a royaltie or a coppy-hould.
A royaltie is ≈øuch a new bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, which in regard of the greatne≈ø≈øe thereof belongeth peculiarly to the King.
Or a royaltie is an inuention Mechanicke which produceth extraordinarie and worthie yearely profits and reuenewes, who≈øe valuation exceedeth the ≈øumme of ten thou≈øand pounds. per annum.
R. 83. Define a coppy-hould inuention.
A. A Coppy-hould is an inuention who≈øe yearely valuation and worth exceedeth not the ≈øumme of ten thou≈øand pounds. per annum.
84. What cannons or rules haue you concerning royall or coppy-hould Inuentions.

A. The≈øe Cannons belong to a Royall Inuention, fir≈øt, no ≈øubiect or ≈øubiects, of what e≈øtate or degree ≈øoeuer by his ≈øeruice or demerit, except the Queene mother, the Kings children, is capeable of a whole entire royaltie, and therefore if the King haue pa≈ø≈øed away
way a royaltie, ignorantly, he may iu≈øtly recall and reuoke his graunt.
Secondly, a ≈øubiect may by his ≈øeruice to his Prince and Country, demerit part or portion of a royaltie, it being no greater then a Coppy-hould.
R. 85. What Cannons or Rules belong to a Mechanicke in re≈øpect of priuiledge or impriueledge.

A. Fir≈øt, it is mo≈øt rea≈øonable and fitting that a Mechanicke inuention ≈øhould be priueledged for a certaine time wholly to the Inuentioner & Authour, if ≈øo be it be but of the yearely valew of a Coppy-hould.
Secondly, the fir≈øt Inuentor of a Royaltie though of meane degree hath as great demerit in the inuention, as any other ≈øubiect of what e≈øtate or degree ≈øoeuer, excepting Royall per≈øons.
R. 86. What Cannons or rules haue you concerning Royalties.

A. There are diuers other rules and ob≈øeruations which I ≈øpare to ≈øpeake of at this time, becau≈øe at further lea≈øure I purpo≈øe to Print a little Tractate of Royalties and coppy-houlds, which is a parcel of this treati≈øe of Metallita.

div.head: CAP. 12. Cannons or rules ≈øeruing to iudge of the goodne≈ø≈øe of a deriuatine Inuention Emporeuticall.
div.p: R
87 How may tho≈øe who are willing to deale in the triall of new inuentions iudge of their goodnes.

A. There are many infallible Rules by which if a diriuatiue Inuention be examined, wee may ea≈øily iudge of the goodne≈ø≈øe thereof, but to reduce this doctrine to ≈øome head, we are to con≈øider both the generall vertues, and generall faults in inuentions.
R. 88. What are the generall virtues by which an Inuention is to be examined.
The vertues of an Inuention are of two degrees, the le≈ø≈øer and the greater, and each degree is three-fould.
R. 89. Which are the le≈ø≈øer virtues of a deriuatiue Inuention.

A. Fir≈øt, the Lenicke In≈øtruments ferue very fitly for the tempering, ≈øtamping, and comixing of Seacole, or Stone-cole, that a kinde of ≈øub≈øtance being there made of them like vnto pa≈øt or tempered clay, the Pre≈ø≈øe-mould may ≈øorme and tranfigure that clay-like ≈øub≈øtance into hollow pipe. cole as it doth earthen pipes.
Now this pipe-coale is of very good v≈øe for the making and working of ≈øome kinds of Irons and ≈øteeles.

Secondly the Lenicke In≈øtrument ≈øerueth very fitly for the breaking and bru≈øing, ≈øtamping and beating, tempering and impa≈øtening of all kinde of Iron oares, whereby they are prepared for the Furnace in a very beneficiall manner and cour≈øe, for when this impa≈øted oare is by the-engin of the Pre≈ø≈øe-mould Intubated and formed into pipes, as if it were Clay or loame, The≈øe oare-pipes being made hollow and full of holes are ≈øooner melted and con≈øumed by the heate of the
furnace and with farre ≈ømaller charges of fewell or firing then the ordinary oare which Founders put into their furnace in peeces or gobbits as great as wallnuts.

R. 120. You hauing handled ≈øufficiently the doctrine of the Lenickes or Pre≈ø≈øing in≈øtruments, I pray you proceede end ≈øhew me what you meane by Plegnickes, which your Maun≈øcript maketh the ≈øecond kinde of your Metallicall In≈øtruments.
A. Plegnicks and Metallicall in≈øtruments which performe their opperation and effect by meanes of their dexterous and artificiall ioynt-mouing.
R. 121. How many kindes of Plegnicke in≈øtruments be there.
A. There are fiue kindes of Plegnicke engins or Machins, the Plegnicke Bellowes, the Plegnicke Milne the Plegnicke Schrew, and the Plegnicke Rombus, and the Reciprocall Plegnicke.
R. 122. What odds and prerogatiue differences is there betweene the ordinary bellowes (which Smithes and Mettle-founders daily v≈øe) and your new deui≈øed Plegnicke bellowes.

A. There are many differences, fir≈øt the Plegnicke bellowes is more hand≈øomely and ≈øtrongly made, then ordinary refining bellowes, and with farre le≈ø≈øe expence of leather, for here the leather is not clo≈øely nailed vpon the wood, but ≈øtrongly gra≈øted and incorporated into the very ≈øub≈øtance of the timber, ≈øo that by this meanes the ioytning of the leather and the wood together, is as thite and clo≈øe as the ≈øub≈øtance
of the boords them≈øelues.

Secondly the Plegnick bellowes may be made to blow and ≈øtreame forth not only could wind and ayre (which is all that ordinary bellowes can doe) but al≈øo to blow and ≈øend forth flames of fire, water, vapours and du≈øt, all which is very nece≈ø≈øary for the blowing of Metallicque ≈øub≈øtances, as ≈øhall be at large ≈øhewed in the ≈øecond Edition or in the Appendix called Plegnica.
Thirdly the Plegnick bellowes may ≈øo be made and contriued, to blow ten times more then the ordinary bellowes, and that either by moouing ten times fa≈øter, or el≈øe by being made ten times greater.
R. 123. What odds and prerogatiue differences is there betweene the ordinary Milnes and your new deui≈øed Plegnick Milnes.
A. The Plegnick Milnes haue many prerogatiues and conueniences which the ordinary Milning lacketh: and to begin with the Wind milne.

list.item: Fir≈øt the ordinary Wind-milne hath nor only his ≈øailes mounted vp in the wind, but al≈øo the work-hou≈øe wherin the Milne-≈øtones and the Cogg-wheeles grind the corne, by which meanes they are ≈øubiect to bee blowne downe with ≈øtormes, but the Plegnick Wind-milne hath his worke-hou≈øe vpon the firme ground, by meanes whereof you may make your Roomes as wide and as large as you will without any hazard or danger of blowing downe.

Secondly the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øailes of the Wind-milne doe mooue verte callter, as they cal it, or through the zeneth
or the nader; wherevppon ari≈øeth this inconuenience that the Wind-milne mu≈øt be turned and haled about continually as the wind changeth, but the Plegnick Wind-milne hath his cro≈ø≈øe-≈øailes ouer the top of the work-hou≈øe, and they flye round about with a circular motion, paralel to the Horizon: whereby it is ready for all windes without turning or haling about.

Thirdly this Plegnick deui≈øe may be made to go with three or foure paire of Milne-≈øtones at once, whereas the wind-milne can go only but with one paire, and by this meanes the Plegnick Wind-milne will grind three or foure times more meale in an houre, e≈øpecially in a good gale of wind.

Fourthly the Wind-milne grindeth only corne, and cannot be made to do any other worke, as the water-milne doth, but the Plegnick engin doth all manner of workes, it will grind corne as well as the Wind-milne, it will ≈øerue for the Iron furnace to blow the bellowes as well as the ordinary Water-milne, and finally to do any other worke which the Water-milne or Hor≈øe-milne doth.

Fiftly the Wind milne ≈øtandeth ≈øtill in a calme and when the wind ≈øerueth not, for there is no meanes to make it goe but by wind, but the Plegnick milne is perpetuall, for when the wind ≈øerueth not, it is made to go with hor≈øe, and in a ≈ømall gale of wind the hor≈øe may help to draw and mooue it fa≈øter.

Sixtly there are al≈øo many other conueniences in the Plegnick Water-milne ouer and aboue the ordinary water milne as more at large ≈øhall bee ≈øhewed in the
≈øecond edition of this treati≈øe.

div.p: R. 124. How many ≈øorts of Plegnick milnes are there in regard of the force that mooueth the Engin.

There are fiue ≈øorts of Plegnick milnes, The fir≈øt is called the Hor≈øwin becau≈øe it mooueth both with hor≈øe and wind, the ≈øecond kind is called the Hor≈øewater becau≈øe it goeth both by hor≈øe and water, The third kind is called the windwater, becau≈øe the Wind and the water mooueth the engin ioyntly together.

The fourth kind is called the Hor≈øwinwater becau≈øe it is mooued with hor≈øe, wind and water alltogether, and at one time. The fi≈øt kind is called the water Plegnick which mooueth either inui≈øibly and ≈øecretly vnder the water and by the water with one rong wheele or elce with two Horizontall wheeles aboue the water.
R. 125. Did you euer make any of the≈øe Plegnick milnes to experiment their goodne≈ø≈øe by triall.

A. I haue made diuers milne engins to go both by wind and water, in the moddle, but not in the grand Mechanick, and I haue at this pre≈øent a hor≈øwin now framing at Highbury, which the next terme God willing ≈øhall ≈øtand vppon ≈øome Turret in London neere vnto the Thames ≈øide, where all pa≈ø≈øengers by water may ≈øee it goe and mooue continually. I haue al≈øo at Pickle herring ouer again≈øt the Tower a water. legnick which mooueth only by the water, and goeth very ≈øwift with two paire of Milne-≈øtones, who≈øoeuer
is de≈øirous to ≈øee it may haue it there at a ≈øhip-Carpenters yard vppon the Wharfe. And thus much of the Plegnick milne.
R. 126. Define the Plegnick Screw, the Plegnick Rhombus, and the reciprocall Plegnick, which are the three la≈øt kinds of your Plegnick Engins.

A. The plegnick ≈øcrew is an engin who≈øe ≈øpirall line mooueth with one motion, two vice nutts or Matrixes at the ≈øame time, which no other ≈øcrew did before, This plegnick ≈øcrew is very auaileable in Metallicall workes, aboue any other ordinary ≈øcrew, which hath beene v≈øually in the common wealth, but e≈øpecially it is very conuenient for tempering, beating and impa≈øtening of all kind of oares and pitcoales
The plegnick Rhombus is an Engin of extraordinary and admirable power and faculty, and in regard of quick and ≈øpeedy motion there was neuer any Machin yet deui≈øed, which commeth neere vnto it.

The Reciprocall Plegnick is an Engin that hath wheeles running reciprocally, turning backwards and forewards by one great wheele that mooueth but one way at the ≈øame time which kind of reciprocal motion was neuer done or performed before by any other Engin.
This reciprocall is of great v≈øe for the battering and beating of Iron, lattin, plate, copper, or any other mettles.

If any be de≈øirous to be further certified concerning the truth of the admirable motions, opperations and workes of the≈øe three engins, let them repaire to Highbury, and it ≈øhall be enidently ≈øhewed and demon≈øtrated vnto them, in diuers reall moddles and examples.

div.head: CAP. 15. Caminicke in≈øtruments, as fewels, liquours and furnaces defined.
div.p: 127. Hauing de≈øcribed the Lenicke and Plegnicke in≈øtruments, I pray you proceed to the third kinde of Metallicall in≈øtruments, which you call by the name of Caminicks.
A. Caminicks are peculiar Metallicall in≈øtruments, which performe their opperation and effect by their new kinde of furnacing and hearthing.
R. 128. How many kindes of Caminicke in≈øtruments be there which ≈øerue for the making of all kinde of Irons and other mettles and materials.
A. There are three kindes, the fewell, the liquor, and the furnace.
R. 129. Define fewell.
A. Fewell is any ≈øub≈øtance combu≈øtible being apt or fit to burne, or to make, or take fier.
R. 130. Rehear≈øe the ≈øeuerall kindes and ≈øorts of fewell.
A. There are three ≈øorts of Fewell, whereof fire is made: Wood-fewell, which is either Char-coale or vnburnt Wood-fewell. Secondly Pit-coale or Earthcoale, and thirdly Bru≈øh-fewel.
Char-cole is the Principall and be≈øt for v≈øe, but by rea≈øon of ≈øcar≈øity it is growne very deare in our country.

Earth-coale is that kinde of fewell of ≈øiring, which is digged out of the bowels of the earth, or el≈øe vpon the ≈øuperficies of the earth, of which ≈øort al≈øo there are many kindes, hauing difference in their burning. The Scotti≈øh coale is the be≈øt flamer, and con≈øumeth away into white a≈øhes, as hauing in it more vnctiou≈øne≈ø≈øe then ≈øulpharou≈øne≈ø≈øe. The New-Ca≈øtle coale, v≈øually called Sea-coale, is more la≈øting and dureable then the Scotti≈øh, for beeing ≈øtirred vp, it will make a ≈øecondary or third fire, whereas the Scotti≈øh-coale con≈øumeth at once; For which cau≈øe all Brewers and artificers of London rather v≈øe this ≈øort. Howbeit it is not ≈øo fit for ≈øome Metalique purpo≈øes as Scotti≈øh-coale, by rea≈øon of the more aboundant heauy ≈øulpherous ≈øub≈øtance remaining in it.

Turffe and Peate maketh a third kinde of earth-coale, and if they haue any ≈øulpharou≈øne≈ø≈øe in them, it is not ≈øo heauy and fretting as that which is in the Sea-coale and Stone-coale, the Low-countries v≈øe for the mo≈øt part this kinde of fewell, in≈øteed of wood & ≈øea-coale.

Bru≈øh-fewell is the third kind of firing, which is neither of the inward ≈øub≈øtance of the earth, nor of the vpper ≈øuperficies as Sea-coale and Turffe is, but groweth vpon the earth in a bru≈øhie or twiggie manner, of this ≈øort is all kinde of ≈øtubble, Baueings, Straw, Furs, Fearne, Ling, Heath, with other ≈øtalkes, of hearbes,
weeds, and vnder-≈øhrubs, all which burne with great flames, yet are they of no great heate or long continuance. Vnder Bru≈øh-fewell, wee comprehend al≈øo an other ≈øort, which is not ≈øo much v≈øed for firing, as for lights, as namely, oyles, tallowes, waxes, which are v≈øed in lampes and candles. Secondly, pitch, ro≈ø≈øen, turpentine, tarre, ma≈øtick, with ≈øuch like liquids and gums, as i≈ø≈øue and proceed from trees beeing combu≈øtible. This kind of fewell is mo≈øt fit for the Ventignoll Mechanick, which hath good and profitable v≈øe for many purpo≈øes, where other fewell is not ≈øo fit.
R. 131. What meanes are to be v≈øed to make earth-coale as ≈øeruiceable for Metalique purpo≈øes, as wood or Char-coale.

A. There are three ≈øorts, the fir≈øt is to bring earth-coale to that equallity of heat, that wood or charcoale hath, that is to ≈øay, that it maketh neither hotter nor coulder fire then wood or Charcoale doth: the ≈øecond meanes, is ≈øo to order and prepare pit-coale, that all nociue proprieties, which are aver≈ø≈øe from all Metalique ≈øub≈øtances, may be ab≈øtracted from it, or at lea≈øt de≈øtroyed in it. The third meanes is the Addition and infu≈øion of tho≈øe deficient proprieties, which as they are in char-cole, ≈øo ought they to be found in pit-cole.
R. 132. What meane you by Caminicke-liquores.

A. By Caminicke-liquores I vnder≈øtand diuers kinds of intermixt and compounded waters for the lauing, wa≈øhing and ≈øteeping of all kinde of mettle-Ewres to cau≈øe them the better to yeeld and giue downe their liquid mettle from their ≈ølaggs and cinders.

So that as the Gould-≈ømith hath his waters which will ≈øegar gould from ≈øiluer, and the Allom-maker his vrines for the ≈øegaring and bringing downe of his allomes,
≈øo the≈øe Caminicke-liquoures are very behoofefull and effectfull for the ≈øteeping and tempering of oares, which being thereby prepared, they will the more ea≈øily let downe their pure mettle being ≈øeuered and ab≈øtracted from the recrement and dro≈ø≈øe of the cinder and the ≈ølagg.
R. 133. Define a furnace.

A. A ≈øurnace is a Caminicke in≈øtrument made and built of furnace-earth; or a furnace is the Artificiall receptacle of fier and fewell, for boyling, nealing, and backing of all kinde of Rawe-materials or Rawe-matters.
R. 134. How many kindes of Rawe-matters are there for furnaces to worke vpon.
A. There are fiue ≈øorts of Rawe-matters, the mettle-matter, the liquour-matter, the fiery earth-matter, the dry matter and compounded-matter.
R. 135. De≈øcribe more plainely the≈øe ≈øeuerall kinds of Rawe-matters.
A. The Mettle-matter is that Mettellar ≈øub≈øtance which is put into the Furnace to be baked, boyled or nealed, which in one word may be called the Mettellar.
R. 136. How many kindes of Mettellars are there
A. There are three ≈øorts of Mettellars.

The fir≈øt is the raw or baked oare, as it is digged out of the earth, which being put into the furnace melteth downe into two ≈øub≈øtances, the one is called the Gla≈øs-≈ølag, and th'other the Sowe-liquour.

The Gla≈ø≈øe-≈ølage is a liquid materiall of a gla≈ø≈øie ≈øub≈øtance being tough, thicke, and ropy, like bird-lime, it ≈øwimmeth vpon the ≈øuperficies of the ≈øowe liquour, as barme doth vpon beare, or creame vpon milke.

The ≈øecond kinde of Mettellar is the ≈øowe of Iron which when the hearth or furnace hath receiued it, it melteth downe into two ≈øub≈øtances, whereof one is called Ferrica ≈øub≈øtantiae, or the Iron ≈øub≈øtance, the other is called the cinder or after-≈ølagg.
The after-≈ølagg is a liquid materiall which inhereth in the Ferrica-≈øub≈øtantiae, as whey doth in a po≈ø≈øet, or crudds.

The Ferrica-≈øub≈øtantiae is tougher then the liquour of the alter-≈ølagg, which when it is battred vnder the ≈øtroke and pre≈ø≈øe of the hammer, the after-≈ølagg is ≈øquea≈øed and pre≈ø≈øed out, and ≈øo the ≈øubstance is made and becometh good Iron, euen as the whey is wrung out by the violence of the Pre≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo the cruds are made into a chee≈øe.

The third kinde of Mettellar is the could Iron, which when the fordge, furnace or hearth receiueth it, it is nealed and heated into glowing Iron, which glowing Iron afterward is forged by the Smith into diuers Emporeutickes for many-fould v≈øes and purpo≈øes, as namely into kniues, hor≈øe-≈øhooes, Iron-weapons, windowe barres, window ca≈øe-ments, and into a thou≈øand ≈øuch like Emporeuticks, whereby Smiths get their liuing and maintenance.
R. 137. In the definition of your Furnace, you make mention of Furnace-earths, I pray you what meane you by them.
A. Furnace-earth, is any earthy ≈øub≈øtance, beeing made and prepared of ≈øtone, clay, or lome, that ≈øo it may become the fit and ≈øufficient matter for the Caminick Furnace.
R. 138. How many kindes of Furnace-earths are there where, withall you build vp your Furnaces.

There are three ≈øorts of Furnace-earths. The fir≈øt is the clay-pipes made of white clay, being tempered, wrought, and impa≈øtned with the du≈øts and pouders of diuers other things. The ≈øecond kinde of Furnace-earth, is the clammy morter, which is of the ≈øame ≈øub≈øtance and temper that the Clay pipes are. The third kinde of Furnace earth, is the Furnace-≈øtone, which is made into diuers figures, formes and proportions by the Pre≈ø≈ø-mould Art, and of the ≈øame matter that the other two kinds were made of before.
R. 139. Define the ≈øecond kind of Rawe-matters, which you call the Liquour-matter.

A. The liquor matter is any kind of liquor or liqueable, whether it be cold or hot, which is put into the Furnace Pot, Kettle, Caldron or Copper, to be further heated, and boyled, as namely, all kinds of fatts, tallows, oyles, and all kinds of waters, whether ≈øimple or compound, as fre≈øh-water, Sea-water, Allom≈ø-water, Coppre≈ø≈øe-water, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch kindes of liquours.
R. 140. Define the third kinde of Rawe-matters which you call fiery-earths.

A. Fiery-earth is any kind of earth or earthy ≈øub≈øtance be≈øides the Mettler which before was de≈øcribed, as namely all kind of Rawe Pre≈ø≈øe-wares and burnt-earths, before they are burned, baked or nealed, neuerthele≈ø≈øe the Raweoare if it be but nealed or baked belongeth to this kinde.
R. 141. Define the fourth kinde of Rawe-matters which you call dry-matters.

A. Dry-matter is any kinde of Rawe-matter be≈øides the three former which were de≈øcribed before, vnder this head wee comprehend all kinde of pa≈øtes for bread, malts, ≈øafrons, papers, wet cloathes &c.

R. 142. Define the fift kinde of Rawe-matter which
you call compounded matter.
A. Compounded matter is any two or more of the former kindes, comming and i≈ø≈øuing from one furnace and from one fire, together, and at the ≈øame time.

R. 143. Hauing thus handled and de≈øcribed the ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of Rawe-matters, which are the things that the ≈øtomack of the Furnace worketh vpon, labouring to dige≈øt boile, and concoct them, I pray you now proceed to the di≈øtributions of the Frunace.

A. The Furnace in re≈øpect of the ≈øeuerall kinds of Raw-matters which it boileth and baketh, is likewi≈øe of fiue ≈øorts and kinds, namely the Mettelar-furnace, the liquor-furnace the fier-earth-furnace; the dry-matter-furnace, and the compounded-furnace.
R. 144. Define the≈øe fiue ≈øeuerall ≈øorts.

A. The Mettallar-furnace heateth, melteth & nealeth all kind of Mettallers, and ≈øo worketh them into their Emporeutick Materials, vnder this head is comprehended all kind of Iron Furnaces or hearths, for any other kind of mettles.
The de≈øcriptions of the other foure kindes of furnaces may ea≈øily be gathered by this, and therefore I referre the further explication of them vntill ≈øome other time.

R. 145. What odds and perogatiue differences are there between the ordinary furnaces which refiners and mettle-founders daily v≈øe, & your new deui≈øed Caminick furnaces. A. There are many differences both in regard of the forme & figure of making of them, as al≈øo in re≈øpect of other conueniences and prerogatiues, whereof the≈øe are principall.

list.item: 1. Fir≈øt our Caminick Furnace is made and built vp of ≈øuch dureable Furnace-matter, and continually maintained with ≈øuch fier-re≈øi≈øting meanes, that it cannot po≈ø≈øibly melt or burne down by any reuerberating flames or heates what≈øoeuer.

2. Secondly, our Caminick Furnace is alwayes built
with ≈øome moueable part, as namely the dores, Fewel-beare, matter-beare and the A≈øh-beare, or any other part as wee plea≈øe.

3. Thirdly our Caminick Furnace is built vp with gla≈ø≈øe windowes for euery ≈øeuerall roome, ≈øo that thereby the Furnar may continually ≈øee and behold both his Rawe-matters and his Emporeutick Materials, and how his fire and Furnace worketh vpon them, which is a ≈øingular conuenience which our ordinary Furnaces want.

div.p: The≈øe forenamed differences and conueniences, with many others, ≈øhall be truly ≈øhewed and demon≈øtrated in the ≈øeuerall examples of our Caminick Furnaces, which very ≈øhortly (God willing) ≈øhall be rai≈øed and built vp at Highbury and at I≈ølington.
R. 146. What & how many are the generall parts of your furnace, which are to be fouÃÑd in euery kind of your Camin.
A. The≈øe fiue, the dores, the windows, the fewell-beare, the Matter-beare, and the A≈øh beare.

R. 147. What and how many are the roomes of your Furnace which are to be fouÃÑd in euery kind of your Caminicks
A. There are foure ≈øeuerall roomes, which are to bee found in euery Furnace, the A≈øh-roome, the Fewell-roome, the Matter-roome, and the Vent-holes.

The a≈øhroome receiueth and holdeth the a≈øhes, the fewell roome, the fewell and firing. The matter-roome receiueth and holdeth the raw-matter. The lower-vent holes receiue and take in the aire, and the vpper vent-holes lets out the ≈ømoake

R. 148. Hauing thus de≈øcribed your three principall Metallicall In≈øtruments called by the names of Lenicks, Plegnicks, and Caminicks, I pray you de≈øcribe your other Metallicall In≈øtruments which you called before the Le≈ø≈ø-principall.
A. There are indeed diuers other Metallicall In≈øtruments which are propper and peculiar of the Authors Inuention, all which ≈øhall be ≈øhewed and de≈øcribed vnto you in the ≈øecond Edition.
R. 149. To what end and purpo≈øe do you publi≈øh the treati≈øe of Metallica in print, which de≈øcribeth and di≈øcouereth all the cheefe In≈øtruments of your Inuentions.
A. There are diuers rea≈øons which mooued the Author to de≈øcribe publiquely to the view of the world the≈øe his Metallicall Arts and Inuentions.
Fr≈øt that it might appeare that his inuentions are new, and of his owne deui≈øing, and not ≈øtolne from any other.

Secondly it is fit and rea≈øonable that that which was granted in the Pattent by generall wordes and in an implicit manner ≈øhould be ≈øo ≈øpecially expre≈øt and defined, that the endeauors and Inuentions of other men being different from his, might not be preuented by him.

Thirdly that none heereafter ≈øhould pre≈øume to petition or trouble his Maie≈øty concerning any kind or kindes which are de≈øcribed and comprehended in his printed treati≈øe of Metallica, which are all priueledged bu≈øine≈ø≈øes vnto him≈øelfe.

And la≈øtly becau≈øe the Author by Indenture from the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øty is tied and enioyned to print and publi≈øh his booke of his new Metallicall Inuentions before the la≈øt day of Ea≈øter Terme, whereas he is not tyed to any time for the triall of his Inuentions.
